channel.title: Notes on Robert Raynor
channel.description: Recent content in Notes on Robert Raynor

item.title: Digital Abstraction, Coordination, and Verifiable AI
item.description: Thesis: Digital abstraction simplifies coordination by dramatically reducing the complexity of verifiability and enforcement. It is primarily the progress of computation, not game theory, that fuels modern progress in coordination. Since AI happens to be digitally abstracted, it will enable a further revolution in coordination technology. Suppose we want to cooperate in order to avoid some kind of prisoner’s-dilemma-esque tragedy of the commons. A normal pattern here is to agree to cooperate optimistically, and also punish anyone who doesn’t cooperate.

item.title: Notes on Active Inference
item.description: Disentangling the properties of the Active Inference algorithm.

item.title: How intelligence helps (and hurts) alignment
item.description: An initial reaction to AI alignment concerns.

item.title: Differential Privacy and Generalization
item.description: How differential privacy can be used to help solve problems of overfitting in adaptive data analysis.

item.title: Learning and Uniform Convergence
item.description: First post in a series on generalization in machine learning.

item.title: Plenoptic Camera Notes
item.description: Working notes related to the use of a plenoptic camera for estimating depth within a scene.
